Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Forward Funding Year 1-4: Collaborative Research: Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
I/UCRC for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications

1034729 Ohio State University; Sudarsanam Babu
1034695 University of Wisconsin-Madison; Sindo Kou
1034703 Lehigh University; John DuPont
1034628 Colorado School of Mines; Stephen Liu

The Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications will focus on the diverse need for materials in energy industries, and on developing scientific methodologies to join these materials and predict their lifetime. Ohio State University (OSU), University of Wisconsin-Madison (UW), Lehigh University (LU) and Colorado School of Mines (CSM) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with Ohio State University as the lead institution.

The intellectual merit of the proposed center is to "close the gap" between material development and weldability for materials used in the energy industry. The new knowledge generated will be used to (a) extend the life of material joints within the aging energy infrastructure and (b) increasing efficiency in deploying advanced materials for new energy infrastructure. The focus of the proposed center is to also address the critical need for engineering graduates trained in interdisciplinary methodologies to address materials joining for wide range of energy applications. The PIs are proposing the following research areas: joining of existing materials; joining of new advanced materials; joining of dissimilar materials; additive manufacturing for hybrid materials; and life extension of existing joints. The PIs are well-qualified and have adequate resources to conduct the proposed research.

The proposed center will focus on developing joining methodologies that will eventually become core components of the curriculum within welding and joining engineering programs. The proposed Center will also offer mentoring programs for students from different ethnic backgrounds and underrepresented groups. If successful, the scientific methodologies will be used to develop state-of-the-art simulation tools that could benefit several industries.

The defined concept for the center should provide an increase in the opportunity for different industries to participate in fundamental research. The center should provide an organized structure for drawing interest and projects from industry. In addition, the center should improve the potential for better understanding of advanced joining metallurgy.

Institution.Name: Colorado School of Mines
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF – Manufacturing & Materials Joining Innovation Center (Ma2JIC)

Summary of Outcomes of the Colorado School of Mines site

The Coloraod School of Mines Site of Ma2JIC Center has achieved some major accomplishments during the 2017-2018 period. Seven graduate students conducted research towards their M.S. and Ph.D. degrees. Industrial and national laboratory collaborators included Los Alamos National Laboratory, Sandia National laboratory, Honeywell National Security Campus in Kansas City, Devasco International, and Elementum 3D. Research covered welding, cladding and additive manufacturing.

In the direction of weld metal transformation investigation, Drew White obtained his M.S. title working on “Low Oxygen Weld Metal in Hot Wire GTA Welded HSLA Steel”. The major outcome of this work was the additional understanding of the relationship between weld metal oxygen content and microstructural transformation. The work further clarified the formation of acicular ferrite in low oxygen content welds, which contain in general lower densities of second phase particles.

In the direction of cladding, Wesley Ott examined the individual effects of arc thermal spray process parameters on droplet formation and coalescence on drill pipes. Defect density directly impacted the strength of the coating. This study clarified which are the parameters that promoted successful cladding. Wesley, through thermodynamic modeling, was able to design new consumables for cladding of drill pipes.

In additive manufacturing (AM), Devon Gonzales, Cheryl Hawk, Davis Wilson, Ethan Sullivan, and Jordan Ream worked on three different aspects of 3D printing. Devon and Cheryl focused their studies on weldability of additive manufactured materials and laser-material coupling. Davis examined the differences between materials built using different 3D printing processes. They concentrated in laser-based processes (Powder Bed fusion and Direct Energy Deposition). Ethan investigated electron beam additive manufacturing with particular emphasis on cored consumables for these processes. These cored fillers are intended to create metal matrix composite deposits which can provide outstanding opportunities in tailored compositions and enhanced mechanical properties to the deposits. These research programs achieved significant outcomes and clarified the coupling between laser and AM materials as well as the different welding characteristics of different AM products. Microsegregation emerged as the leading variable that caused the different behaviors observed. Heat input (inversely cooling rate) can explain the different fine microstructures and primary solidification structures as well as the mechanical behavior. Their studies established clear advances in understanding AM products and their applicability. and improve the quality and properties of AM assemblies.

These students used advanced material characterization methods and processes. That included electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD), microhardness, nano-indentation, electron microscopy, laser integration sphere, cored wire manufacturing, laser AM, Electron Beam AM, laser-based particle size analyzer, four-point bend testing with digital image correlation (DIC).

The Colorado School of Mines Site provided opportunities for training specialists in the field of materials joining and additive manufacturing and for the development of their ability and experience in those fields of engineering. The Site also provided opportunities to undergraduate students to discover research in engineering and to nurture their interest in research. Researchers of the Colorado School of Mines Site were able to participate in conferences and published in refereed journals and proceedings.

The Colorado School of Mines Site recruited two new students in this research year. Drew White completed his M.S. degree and is currently employed by a former sponsor of Ma2JIC Center.

 

Finally, the findings from the Mines Site projects are directly fed back to the industrial/government members of NSF-Ma2JIC. The possibility of joining AM components to each other and to wrought parts will open up the applicability of AM technology. Identifying the effects of AM processing on welding behavior, in both weld metal and heat affected zone development, holds a key position in further expanding reliable application of AM components in the manufacturing and fabrication industries. The experience in welding filler metal design and manufacturing gained in prior research provided great background for developing specialized filler metals for electron beam freeform fabrication, one of the pillar processes of additive manufacturing.  Alloying element replenishment from these specialized consumables will correct for the losses incurred during deposition and eliminate out of specification deposits.  By minimizing these unnecessary mistakes, cost savings can be achieved.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2018
Modified by: Stephen Liu
